title: Migrant opens up on horror of travelling to UK in refrigerated lorry for 55 days
text:

A man who travelled to the UK from Syria in a refrigerated lorry has relived the ordeal after the tragic deaths of 39 people in Essex.

Ahmad Al-Rashid recounted the harrowing 55 days he was stuck in a truck with frozen meat when he fled the country from the bombings.

Ahmad, who travelled to the UK in 2015, told BBC documentary Exodus: Our Journeys to Europe: "It was freezing cold in there.

(Image: BBC)

"You couldn't do anything. They said: 'That's going to be two hours and this is going to be the end of the matter.'

"After two hours, the lorry didn't move and then people started coughing and started freezing.

"This is when you have to knock and knock and knock and be at the mercy of the smugglers to come and get you out.

"Because it's all locked from outside."

(Image: BBC)

Ahmad said he was one of the lucky ones that made it alive when he and other migrants 'were stuck nearly to death'.

He also stressed that the most difficult and dangerous part of the journey was in Calais, France, due to the high criminal activity around the area.

"Smugglers would be just putting people in the back of lorries and just sending them off, not knowing where they were headed," he added.

(Image: BBC)

He tweeted yesterday following the news and said: "My heart goes out to those who lost their lives en route. Be kind, be the voices of the voiceless. Be a human being."

Paramedics were alerted first after the 39 bodies were discovered at the Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays on Wednesday.

They have since been identified as Chinese nationals.

Mo Robinson, from Portadown, Northern Ireland, was arrested on suspicion of murder and remains in custody for questioning.

Detectives have said the trailer containing the victims arrived at Purfleet from Zeebrugge in Belgium at around 12.30am on Wednesday while the front section to which it was attached came from Northern Ireland.

(Image: Getty Images)

Eric Van Duyse, a spokesman for the Belgian federal prosecutor's office, said that Brussels had started an investigation into the incident.

He added: "We have no idea at the moment how long the lorry spent in Belgium, it could be hours or days, we just don't know."

Speaking on Wednesday afternoon, Deputy Chief Constable Pippa Mills said the lorry and the container were being moved to nearby Tilbury Docks so the bodies can be recovered while preserving the dignity of the victims.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the perpetrators of the crime "should be hunted down", while local MP Jackie Doyle-Price said the people responsible must be caught.

The harrowing incident comes as the National Crime Agency said the number of migrants being smuggled into the UK in containers and lorries has risen in the last year.
description: Syrian Ahmad Al-Rashid recalled his horrendous journey of being stuck in a freezer with frozen chicken and meat
